--- Chad Bohannan <chad@...> wrote:
> 
> > You start with all outputs at zero. As soon as the
> "ready" output is 
> > high, then you are done, and you take all of the
> other outputs as 
> > your result. High could be defined as> .5. I think
> this is a 
> > general approach that applies to many problems.
> Essentially, you are 
> > letting the nework tell you when it is done
> processing. I have used 
> > this approach in two programs, and it worked
> perfectly.
> 
> Can you describe the progams? This sounds like the
> group confidence 
> topic that came up earlier. 

4Play is one of them; it has been discussed here many
weeks ago.  All of the C souce code can be downloaded
from the ANNEvolve website, along with plenty of
documentation.  It is all command line stuff, no
graphics.  In 4Play there were actually 4 "ready"
lines; the processing was condidered done if any of
them went high.

VizANN.py is a GUI program that demonstrates the
detailed operation of a 2-neuron recurrent binary ANN
that does XOR.  With this program you get to see the
ready output in action.

The weight sets for VizANN.py were evolved by a
program which I call xor.c.  This is ready to release;
I expect to release it very soon.  I think I will
release it today! 


=====
Mitchell Timin
